item.title: Tree
item.description: This tree combines family tree information for a few sources, starting from what I am here calling "generation A": Mau-Kong CHENG and WONG Ming Chong. Two finger scroll to zoom in/out Double-click to zoom to person Use slider to scroll through card previews (adopted)

item.title: Dorothy WONG
item.description:
Born on: August 12, 1905 In: Walnut Grove, Sacramento, California, USA Died on: January 31, 1985 In: Los Angeles, California, USA Parents: WONG Ming Chong, JANG Hem Shee
Siblings: John Kuen Hue WONG, Jehim WONG, WONG Sam Tin, Lyda WONG, Abbie WONG
Married: C.C. CHEND
Children: Donaldson CHENG, Louis CHENG, Samuel CHENG, Robert CHENG, Annette CHENG, brother (still born, no name)
Tags: gen_b
On August 12, 1905. Dorothy Chuck Yee Wong was the second child born in the United States (Walnut Grove, CA) for her father WONG Ming Chong and mother JANG Hem. Her father had recently returned from China to bring JANG Hem, pregnant with Dorothy's elder sister Sam Foon WONG. Dorothy's father was a merchant with a partnership in the Chong Sing & Co at the time, located in Walnut Grove, a town on the Sacramento Delta.
The family moved to Watsonville, CA in 1909 so that Dorothy's father could take over the management of then-called Yee Lee Company, changing the name to the Wong Yee Kee Company. Dorothy's three younger brothers and two younger sisters were born.Revolutionary Sun Yat-sen is recalled to have visited Dorothy's home when she was at a young age. The family nickname for Sun Yat-sen was "Uncle Bean," which he earned from eating beans when staying at their place. They shared a hometown of Xiangshan, better known by its current name Zhongshan.
In 1921, at age 16, Dorothy embarked on the with her parents and siblings to return to , China. During this time, Dorothy had also acquired a Kodak Brownie, which she used to photograph her daily life. Dorothy attended the McTyeire School for Girls, a Christian school in Shanghai. Her parents stayed in Shanghai while she and her siblings eventually returning to the US, starting with Jehim.
She met Chee Chinn CHEND while __ and they married in on June 23, 1925, when Dorothy was 19 years old. They had four children, three sons and a daughter. By laws at the time, being a woman and having married a non-citizen meant that Dorthy lost her American citizenship. She encountered difficulty when petitioning for her re-naturalization, and had to present evidence that she had previously lived in the US because she did not possess a birth certificate. High school transcripts from Watsonville allowed her to become re-naturalized. She arrived to San Francisco with her oldest two sons Donaldson and Louis on January 24, 1949, and continued living in the Bay Area.
Meanwhile, C. C. and their younger two children remained in China. Dorothy wrote to he husband to urge him to come to the US soon with the impending control of the Chinese Communist Party over China. She vouched for his eligibility in a letter to the California __ [1].
Donaldson and Louis were attending university in 1949, supported by income from Dorothy's imports store, The Temple Bell. moving to LA, with brother Jehim's precedence LA Chinese Women's Club
Ran the Coral Sea Restaurant and the 5 Lanterns Restaurant LA Chinese Women's club recipe books introducing hot pot to american audience The restaurants were sold after the death of her husband C.C Chend. taught cooking interviewed for local news personal profile
LA Times Obituary
?↩︎
